summary: This is a discovery request letter from Jeffrey Epstein's defense attorneys to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, dated July 26, 2019. The letter requests preservation and production of documents related to the 2007 non-prosecution agreement (NPA) and communications between various U.S. Attorney's Offices, as Epstein's defense intends to file a motion to dismiss the indictment based on the NPA.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced in the document; his defense attorneys are requesting discovery to support a motion to dismiss based on a 2007 non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Martin G. Weinberg
persons.context: Attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein; signs the letter and is listed with his Boston law firm.

persons.name: Reid Weingarten
persons.context: Attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein; signs the letter and is listed with Steptoe & Johnson LLP in New York.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) Signed
events.description: A non-prosecution agreement between the Department of Justice and Jeffrey Epstein, which the defense argues constitutes a global resolution of his then-existing offense conduct.

events.title: Indictment of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: The Southern District of New York returns an indictment against Jeffrey Epstein (case number 19-cr-00490), which this discovery request is related to.

keyFacts: Epstein's defense team is preparing a motion to dismiss the indictment based on the 2007 non-prosecution agreement (NPA).

The defense requests preservation of communications between multiple U.S. Attorney's Offices (Southern District of New York, Southern District of Florida, Middle District of Florida, Northern District of Georgia) and Main Justice regarding Epstein and the NPA.
The letter references the case Jane Doe v. United States (No. 08-cv-80736) in the Southern District of Florida, involving alleged victims.
The defense argues that recent interactions between the Northern District of Georgia and victims' attorneys may be inconsistent with immunity commitments in the NPA.
